11:12 am
BE11:12am

Oh, and we have PMIs if you want actual data to chuck into the void.

BE11:13am

RBC can summarise what's said there.

BE11:13am

The UK’s EU exit day was meant to be at the end of March. For months now, the IHS Markit/CIPS PMIs have been flagging how the uncertainty around what form Brexit would take was affecting the UK economy. With the level of political uncertainty, reaching new heights last month the impact of that on the economy became increasingly clear.

The composite PMI fell to the no-change 50 mark from 51.5 last month. However, that masks a more widespread weakness in the survey with activity in both the services and construction sectors contracting and only Brexit related stockpiling the manufacturing sector keeping the composite above 50.

The services PMI fell to 48.9, to leave it below 50 for the first time since July 2016. Excluding that immediate post-referendum reading, you have to go back to Dec 2012 to find the last sub-50 reading. Markit provide an effective summary in the accompanying press release: “There were widespread reports that domestic political uncertainty had constrained demand in March, with clients hoping for clarity about Brexit outcomes before committing to new projects.”

The manufacturing PMI rose to 55.1 from 52.0 previously as the pace of stockpiling ahead of what was expected to be Brexit day at the end of March accelerated. If firms were working to an end of March deadline than presumably this should be the peak of this effect in the sector. However, if this is just firms bringing production forward that will have to be 'paid back' at some point. For us, combination of the run-down of inventories and weaker global trade mean that the prospects for the sector in coming months are tilted heavily to the downside.

The construction PMI remained below 50 for a second consecutive month. Again, the sector splits between residential work (i.e. houses and apartments) and civil engineering and commercial work. Commercial work is again the worst performing of the three sectors with the accompanying press release from Markit report that “Brexit uncertainty and concerns about the domestic economic outlook had led to risk aversion among clients”.

Clearly, Bexit is affecting activity, however, possibly by not as much as the PMIs are pointing to. The March PMIs have left our PMI-based GDP model pointing to Q1 growth of -0.1% q/q. The January GDP release, however, showed the economy growing by 0.5% m/m suggesting that the PMIs are overstating the extent of the Q1 slowdown and we still expect the economy to register an expansion of 0.2% q/q in Q1.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

So anyway, the Superdry investment case is now a mystery box.

BE11:22am

Here's Stifel.

BE11:22am

The likely U-turn in strategy, in addition to a potential staff turnaround (almost the entire Board resigned today), might extend the expected timeline for a potential brand recovery.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

We think that postponing the CMD, previously scheduled for the end of March, was a strategic mistake by the current management.

BE11:23am

Yeah, hindsight.

BE11:23am

The 100-day plan. Dunkerton has been appointed interim chief executive and Peter Williams has
been appointed as chairman. Having spoken with Dunkerton last week, we expect the following
actions:
• Search for a new CEO;
• Race to "save" Christmas with a new product pipeline sourced from Turkey;
• Childrenswear launch likely to be halted;
• Reduction of sales/discounting;
• Likely change in the US (more East-focused rather than West) and China (push to a franchise
model) strategies;
• Store closures to be limited through “positive” re-engagement with landlords and “store LfL to be
brought back to positive territory”;
• Design Lab to lead innovation and SKUs counts to increase (+15%, in particular online).

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Race to "save" Christmas?! It's April!

BE11:24am

Zara can get tat knocked up in a fortnight based on whatever video game's currently top of Twitch, but it takes Superdry eight months to write some kanji on some t-shirts?

BE11:24am

Whatever.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Uncertainties weigh on FY20 outlook. This represents a reset of the strategy and the timeline required to turnaround the brand, although we could see early results as soon as January 2020. It is not clear what will be the impact on FY20 estimates as the transformation plan and the implied £20m cost savings/store closures might be put on hold.
Valuation. The stock trades at 9.0x 2019 Cal. P/E, a c.30% discount to the sector. The discount
appears justified given the uncertainty connected with the change in strategy. While Dunkerton might have a better shot at turning the brand around, we believe the reset in strategy will likely cause a further delay in the timeline of the promised brand recovery.

BE11:25am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:26am

Recruitment and steadying the ship will be the short-term
priority, although the expected range changes and transition to Julian’s plan will impact short-term costs ahead of any revenue improvement. Julian will no doubt seek to cut the childrenswear range before it lands in late summer, which is likely to involve some form of abortive costs. Julian is also keen to drive stock densities in-store and bring more choice online. The process of dealing with any changes in the leadership team, recruiting a new CEO, firing up the DesignLab and
rushing through new designs will likely drive short-term costs and disruption ahead of any sales benefit, with Julian’s efforts to refresh product lines unlikely to gain real momentum before 2020, albeit he should be able to inject newness into the range with additional lines in time for Christmas and peak trading.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

With the majority of external shareholders voting against Julian’s return, we may see the shares weighed down by short-term changes to the register. We also expect to see Superdry incur additional costs as the business transitions to Julian’s vision, which coupled with what is likely to have been a continued tough trading backdrop, means that short-term forecasts may come under pressure. For us, the key challenge is to reinvigorate the core Superdry proposition, which has suffered from a lack of innovation stemming back over several seasons. From a sub-4x EV/EBITDA and the foundation of a strong balance sheet however, there remains clear long-term value if Julian can quickly steady the ship and re-invigorate product lines.

BE11:27am

And Investec, no longer shop broker.

red ban on dads with beards and glasses and you will immediately improve the brand! its all about image
BigTuna better late than never rice welder
BE11:28am

Little practical detail on proposed 2-3 year strategy to restore EBIT margin to double digits can be gleamed from Mr Dunkerton’s ‘Save Superdry’ website, presentation & press interviews. Time will tell how much of the recent
underperformance was down to weather, product offer, execution or the
consumer backdrop.
 An issue for the brand has always been the profit bias to Christmas and its over-reliance on hoodies, graphic tees and outerwear (accounting for 65%- 70% of FY sales). This proportion has changed little since IPO in 2010 and has always represented an opportunity. We do not believe that bringing back the ‘Design Lab’ and returning to a two season design process as proposed by Mr Dunkerton will fix the clear weakness in the Superdry proposition.

 Recommendation cut to Hold from Buy on increased execution risk. Our
TP, based on a 30% discount to sector CY20 PE, falls to 500p to reflect
increased risk. With 74% of the shareholders (ex Mr Dunkerton & friends)
having voted against the election of Mr Dunkerton & Mr Williams, we expect pressure on the share price in the short term.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Burberry will report FY March 19E preliminary results on 16th of May pre
market open. We anticipate these results to be soft albeit widely
expectedly. We expect H2 19E Sales flat underlying (incl Q4 LFL +2%),
+2% reported to £1,496m and EBIT down 6% to £266m. This would bring
FY19E Sales down 1% reported and underlying to £2,717m and EBIT
down 5% to £444m, or broadly in line with guidance of flattish Sales and
flat margin excl forex once accounting for the £25m hit from forex.
Burberry should also provide its FY March 20E forex impact guidance and
this is notably where it hurts: we have cut our FY March 20E EBIT
estimate by 6% to reflect a meaningfully less favourable GBP move (we
now calculate a c£15m negative impact at EBIT level) bringing us c5%
below Bberg consensus. While we have no doubt that mgt will remain
confident in tone on its brand turnaround progress during its yearly analyst meeting (on the same day), we think there are few signs of a turnaround.

BE11:37am

That's the gist.

red not commercially viable to earn money from overnight charges. to be profitable you need to keep client trades in house.
BE11:40am

The trading update highlights reduced trading activity and expects CFD and spread bet income of £110m for FY 2019, 37% lower than the prior year and lower than the recent guidance of down 25-35% issued in February. We were expecting £127m. Net operating income is expected to be £131m (vs £187m in 2018), and this is below our previous estimate of £148.3m. The statement points to slightly lower costs in 2019, we expect more details at the FY results on 6 June. Our PBT and EPS forecasts for 2019 come down by 75%. The group remains confident in meeting the 2020 and 2021 consensus numbers, having seen a stabilisation of client money and new client numbers. Retail client trading appears to have stabilised, and the revenue shortfall appears to relate to lower market volatility. We have left our dividend forecast unchanged, even though this in not now covered in 2019. The CFO, Grant Foley, has announced his resignation, and currently intends to remain with the Group (he remains on the Board) for the next six months to ensure a smooth transition. Separately, David Fineberg, currently Group Commercial Director, will be appointed Deputy Chief Executive Officer. We reduce our price target price to 80p and maintain our HOLD recommendation.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Or if that's too much to read, Morgan Stanley.

BE11:41am

For the FY19 (March year-end), CMC announced that revenues are expected to be ~£131m, which is ~2.5% below Bloomberg consensus £134.6m. Management will exercise some cost discipline to help mitigate the impact on earnings.
Bloomberg consensus expects PBT of ~£13m and EBITDA of ~£25m. Assuming half of this revenue loss can be offset by cost reductions would imply ~7% of EBITDA and ~13.5% of profits.
Revenues of £131m would be down ~30% YoY, driven by structural factors – i.e. the EU regulation clamping down on CFD and spread betting products – as well as cyclical factors – tough market backdrop with less trading activity.
Management is guiding that the impact from regulations is starting to stabilise.

Mouselet Good morning assorted energetic and competent capitalists.
BE11:43am

Weird that, while CMC's CFD and spread-betting revenues will be down 37%, the Australian stockbroking business has become the only bit of the business that's growing.

11:44 am

undefined

Stagecoach Group PLC (SGC:LSE): Last: 164.10, up 9.3 (+6.01%), High: 174.70, Low: 160.10, Volume: 857.90k

SoS Not much under Jeremy Corbyn
BE11:49am

Still, it's not a warning. That's something. Here's Jefferies.

NoRobots @SoS just thinking the same thing
11:49 am
BE11:50am

Given ongoing strength in trading and in UK Rail, Stagecoach now
expects higher adjusted EPS for FY19 versus previous guidance. Divisional LFLs, for the forty weeks ending 2nd March: UK Bus (regional operations) +3.4% (JEFe FY19 +1.3%), UK Bus (London) +1.3% (JEFe FY19 -2.3%) and UK Rail (JEFe FY19 -63%) and North America LFL -1.4% (JEFe FY19 +3.7%).
Detail: Pricing continues to help regional bus, with LFL vehicle miles operated -0.5%, but revenue per vehicle +4% yoy. Commentary that the bidding environment in London bus remains highly competitive, which is putting pressure on margins.
Megabus trading is disappointing, with LFL revenue -1.9% yoy. UK Rail and Virgin Rail Group performances are ahead, with positive profit impact from favourable outcomes in ongoing contractual matters surrounding SWT franchise. We see these as short-term supports, especially given franchise expiry. Following the update, we would expect low single digit upgrades to consensus EPS for FY19E.

BE11:50am

And Citi.

urgeview @OnYourRight, they think its good enough for you. Question is do they wear Superdry though...reckon, no.
BE11:51am

Most of Stagecoach's bus and rail divisions have shown improving
momentum with this trading update and compared to the H1 results in December (April year-end). As such, management is now somewhat more positive in their outlook for FY earnings.
 Momentum across the divisions — UK Bus saw like-for-like growth of 3.4% in the first 44 weeks of the fiscal year which is in line with that seen at the H1 results.
London Bus revenue has seen a small improvement to +1.3% revenue growth (+0.2% at H1) although management caution that the bidding environment for new contracts remains very competitive. The North American divisions, soon to be sold off, saw the decline in revenue growth of 3% for H1 improve to a decline of 1.4%; the sale of that division is still expected to complete by financial year-end. The UK
Rail division (ex-Virgin) also saw modest improvement in like-for-like revenue growth of +1.4% (+0.4% at H1).

11:51 am
BE11:51am

 Implications — Given some improvement in growth metrics and management more highlighting improved FY earnings expectations, we would expect the shares to perform well today.

Tom Dalgleish Superdry should do a gilet jaune range
wayneJ It seems to me that previous management at SuperDry was desperate to achieve analyst revenue forecasts by pumping stock into wholesale and also by price cutting. Based on how SuperDry used to run I suspect there is some short term pain due to the need to 'destock' the channel. Also going back to full price is going to lead to short term pain.
BE11:53am

PE of less than 8 forward and a 7.7p divi .... Headline net debt/EBITDA at the full year 2019 at 1.4x .....

wayneJ There also seemed to be some quality deterioration at SuperDry which hopefully, Mr Dunkerton will be able to fix.
BE11:54am

And East Coast rail now exited so you're thinking that might be ringfenced?

OnYourRight @urgeview: I think you have made a good point. I think they were buying Jack Willis but dad got a cheap Super D cast off.
wayneJ But the main issue was the attempt by the previous management to do 'brand extension' - and that resulted in alienation of its core customers.
11:54 am
BE11:55am

And an equity free cashflow yield from the non-rail side of 10% ... I mean, it's not hard to make a valuation argument here.

NoRobots SuperDry's core customers are growing up, and the new generation will want something new.
wayneJ Also though it is trading near book value there is a serious question to be asked about how much software / website capitalisation do retailers need on their balance sheet. And with new IFRS rules there is also the issue of bringing shop leases onto the balance sheet.
wayneJ Losing your CFO in such circumstances is 'unfortunate'.
BE11:56am

.... If it weren't for the very very big political and management/ownership risks..

BE11:56am

RBC buying. FWIW.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Bus only and rump rail scenarios suggest 168p-188p: Though not used
to set our PT, in Exhibit 8 we refresh the range of value scenarios for
the shares’ outlook. Key is that with only rail value for the ‘rump’ of
existing rail contracts, we assume (in this scenario) that Manchester and
Newcastle Bus EBITDA was to be lost to franchising and then the rest of
UK Bus margins saw attrition to 7%-8% (from 9.6% 2020E base case).
• Flexors: However, this might change and see: (1) significant upside if bus
franchising and margin risk was to reduce materially; (2) If excess capital
(below 2x ND/EBITDA) was deployed to M&A, this could add 24p/share;
and (3) UK rail operations continue to see delays to new franchises,
so we see likely meaningful value but short duration EPS upside from
extensions to present contracts and/or short life new contracts - as the
DFT falls yet further behind its franchise timetable.
• O/P - PT lifts to 190p: Our updated SoTP based PT using Exhibit 11
sees longer-term investors rewarded with a 5% FY19E DPS yield (at spot
share price). Our PT implies 12.1x 2019/20E PER vs. ~10.8x 1994-2018
historical. It implies 17x PER FY2020/21E (when minimal rail EBIT is left
in our projections) vs. 13.3x ex Rail PER (21-year median).
• As the outlook stabilises we see scope for the achieved PER multiple to
expand as: (1) Low bond yields imply a higher (than long-term average
PER) value for cash generative UK bus. (2) The business profit mix
potentially moves away from low multiple UK Rail (even though the
company itself sees more value in Rail than we find from investors.) (3) If
accretive UK Bus M&A is made (buying under managed bus operations).

undefined
BE11:58am

Oh, note just through from Ian Gordon at Investec.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Who's calling the top in StanChart.

BE11:58am

STAN shares are up 13% in 6 days, which represents a fresh 7-month high.
Given our belief that a “final” settlement with the US authorities may be
imminent, this move is, we think, justified. However, with no residual upside to our (unchanged) 630p TP, we are obliged to downgrade back to Hold (from Buy). We advise taking profits, with a switch into UK domestic/specialist banks; our top pick is OneSavings Bank (Buy) or Lloyds (Buy) within the FTSE100.

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 649.60, up 17 (+2.69%), High: 651.20, Low: 628.00, Volume: 4.30m
